A Guide to Water Conservation - Saving Water and our mother Earth

    Key Facts about our water:

  • The average adult human body is composed of 50-65 percent water, averaging around 57-60 percent. With infants, they have a much higher percentage, typically around 75-78% water, dropping to 65% by one year of age.
  • The Earth has a limited amount of water. The water we have now is all we get, it is recycled over and over. The water cycle can help you understand this condition.
  • Plantâ€™s life is dependent on water. Plants help the ecosystem and produce oxygen that is necessary to keep us healthy. Additionally, trees are generally used for housing, paper, and a lot more.
  • Water is the basic requirement for every food. It grows our fruits and vegetable and it is consumed by each livestock.

    Saving WATER really is IMPORTANT!

    Since safe and clean water is limited, people who have access to fresh water can take steps to control their consumption of water to avoid waste and shortage. We know that the planet is mostly covered with saltwater and can only be consumed after undergoing a desalination process, which is quite expensive. Saving water really means a lot not only to humans but to all the species on Earth.

    Water is Life!

    Everything on Earth necessitates water to sustain itself. But abusing it means that we are reducing its ability to provide us with this basic necessity. Water is a limited resource and while Earth is a self-contained ecosystem, the planet always has, and will always have, the same amount of water. The population growth puts a strain on water supplies, and clean water is reduced by the pollution and contamination the human kind creates.

    Without fresh water, one will die in just a short span of time. It is a simple yet morbid fact that helps drive the point across, water is life. Water conservation is the potential, the most cost-effective and environmentally sound way to reduce the demand for water.

    Benifits of water saving in day to day life

    Saving Water Saves Energy

    A lot of energy is required to treat water and supply it to your home, similarly as a tremendous amount of water is expected to cool the power plants that produce electricity.

    At home, heating water for showers, shaving, cooking and cleaning likewise utilizes a lot of energy.

    That is the reason it's imperative to recollect to save energy and water in your home. We tend to have longer, hotter showers as the climate gets colder. By placing a water efficient shower and lessening the time spent in the shower you can spare energy and water.

    Did you know that?
  • Heated water utilizes 39% of energy in the typical home.
  • Washing your garments in cold water can decrease energy use by up to 80% when compared with a warm wash stack.
  • Putting up a water-efficient showerhead can lessen your expenses by up to $100 every year.
    • Saving Water Saves Money

    Using less water, it makes your money in your pocket. Through employing basic water conservation strategies, you may be able to save thousands of gallons of water every year.

    In addition, water conservation can help prevent water pollution. Overloading a septic system may cause nutrient and bacterial contamination of nearby lakes, streams and drinking water, even the water from your own well. The smaller the amount of water flowing through these systems, the lower the likelihood of pollution.

    Saving Water Saves nature

    Saving water likewise decreases the risk of natural disasters such as droughts. We have to reuse water in the same number of were likely to save a more significant amount of it.

    We have to save water for plants as well. Earth's oxygen and a large portion of the food originate from plants. Plants require water for survival as well.

    Saving water turns out to be critical for up and coming generations. They won't have enough accessibility of water unless we wind up worried from this day at present.

What can we do..???

"We have first to understand that the preservation of water is the obligation of each person. It is to be done as a whole. No government authority or institution can help us in saving water unless we ourselves desire to.Right now is high time to do so."

There are some ways to save water
  • Check your toilet for leaks
  • Stop using your toilet as an ashtray or wastebasket
  • Take shorter showers
  • Install water-saving shower heads or flow restrictors
  • Try to do rainwater harvesting
  • Use your automatic washing machine only for full loads only
  • Don't let the faucet run while you clean vegetables
  • If you wash dishes by hand, don't leave the water running for rinsing
  • Plant drought-resistant trees and plants
  • Don't run the hose while washing your car
  • Tell your children not to play with the hose and sprinklers
  • Rising awareness of water conservation
